title: Syslog Play Store Description: ADB Permission Option for Non-root Devices Missing
body:
Even more people could enjoy [Syslog](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.tortel.syslog) if the app description in Play Store would include the adb set permission option.

This worked perfectly on un-rooted S5 Mini G800H & S5 G900M both running Android stock 6.0.1 and S5 G900M running LineageOS 15.1:

adb shell pm grant com.tortel.syslog android.permission.READ_LOGS

User review by Shahab Jafri in your Play page also mentions it.

You could check the example of [BetterBatteryStats](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.asksven.betterbatterystats) > Unrooted devices chapter & it's [BBS unrooted devices FAQ page](http://better.asksven.org/nonroot-devices/) for inspiration.

Thanks for implementing the [issue 21](https://github.com/Tortel/SysLog/issues/21) suggestion.

_Edit:_ the screen captures also need to be updated. Current in Play page vs. Syslog 2.1.6:


![syslog_play_store](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33857747/46860285-543be000-cdcd-11e8-9d71-9e6417411a7b.png)

title: Add Proper Log's Name in the App Please
body:
I like to recommend Syslog in different forums to newbies because it makes sharing logs for troubleshooting so much easier for them but it's a pain to explain every time that Kernel log = dmesg, Last kernel log= last_kmsg, main log = logcat.

So why not add in parenthesis **in the app itself** the actual real log's name output like what you did in the [Syslog description in Google Play](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.tortel.syslog&hl=en)?

> * Kernel logs (dmsg)
    * Last kernel log (last_kmsg, if device supports it)
    * Main log (Logcat)

Suggestion in red in the attachment:

![syslog_logs_real_name_note](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33857747/34669883-86c74f1e-f439-11e7-87cd-3096f236dc4d.png)

Anyway thank you for this awesome app & for keeping it up-to-date.

title: [Request] audit log
body:
`/data/misc/audit/audit.log`

On many devices this contains a log of SELinux audit failures that may not be present in logcat and/or dmesg output, and can be very handy to help diagnose issues related to security for root apps.
